spcphys_common_functions.parameters package

Submodules

spcphys_common_functions.parameters.alfvenic_parameters module

YAO S, HE J S, TU C Y, et al., 2013. SMALL-SCALE PRESSURE-BALANCED STRUCTURES DRIVEN BY MIRROR-MODE WAVES IN THE SOLAR WIND[J/OL]. The Astrophysical Journal, 776(2): 94. DOI:10.1088/0004-637X/776/2/94. WU H, TU C, WANG X, et al., 2021. Magnetic and Velocity Fluctuations in the Near-Sun Region from 0.1−0.3 au Observed by Parker Solar Probe[J/OL]. The Astrophysical Journal, 922(2): 92. DOI:10.3847/1538-4357/ac3331.

spcphys_common_functions.parameters.alfvenic_parameters.calc_alfven(p_date: List[datetime] | ndarray, v: Quantity, n: Quantity, b_date: List[datetime] | ndarray, b: Quantity, least_data_in_window: int | float = 20)[source]

Calculate the Alfvenic parameters (corrlation coefficient between velocity and magnetic field, residual energy, cross helicity, Alfven ratio, compressibility).

Parameters:

  • p_date – List of datetime objects for proton velocity data.

  • v – Proton velocity data in shape (time, 3).

  • n – Proton number density data in shape (time).

  • b_date – List of datetime objects for magnetic field data.

  • b – Magnetic field data in shape (time, 3).

  • least_data_in_window – Least number of valid data points. Default is 20.

Return {‘r3’:

r3, ‘p3’: p3, ‘residual_energy’: residual_energy, ‘cross_helicity’: cross_helicity, ‘alfven_ratio’: alfven_ratio, ‘compressibility’: compressibility, ‘vA’:vA}: Dictionary of Alfvenic parameters.

spcphys_common_functions.parameters.alfvenic_parameters.calc_alfven_t(p_date: List[datetime] | ndarray, v: Quantity, n: Quantity, b_date: List[datetime] | ndarray, b: Quantity, least_data_in_window: int | float = 20, **slide_time_window_kwargs) → dict[source]

Calculate the Alfvenic parameters (corrlation coefficient between velocity and magnetic field, residual energy, cross helicity, Alfven ratio, compressibility).

Parameters:

  • p_date – List or numpy array of datetime objects for proton velocity data.

  • v – Proton velocity data in shape (time, 3).

  • n – Proton number density data in shape (time).

  • b_date – List or numpy array of datetime objects for magnetic field data.

  • b – Magnetic field data in shape (time, 3).

  • least_data_in_window – Least number of valid data points in each time window. Default is 20.

  • slide_time_window_kwargs – Additional keyword arguments to pass to the slide_time_window function.

Return {‘r3’:

r3, ‘residual_energy’: residual_energy, ‘cross_helicity’: cross_helicity, ‘alfven_ratio’: alfven_ratio, ‘compressibility’: compressibility, ‘vA’:vA}: Dictionary of Alfvenic parameters.

spcphys_common_functions.parameters.alfvenic_parameters.calc_dx(x: Quantity | ndarray, axis=0, **mean_kwargs) → Quantity | ndarray[source]

Remove the mean value from the input array.

Parameters:

  • x – Input array.

  • axis – Axis along which to calculate the mean value. Default is 0.

  • mean_kwargs – Additional keyword arguments to pass to the numpy.nanmean function.

Returns:

Array with the mean value removed, as an astropy Quantity.

spcphys_common_functions.parameters.alfvenic_parameters.calc_va(b: Quantity, n: Quantity, dva: bool = False) → Quantity[source]

Calculate the Alfven velocity.

Parameters:

  • b – Magnetic field data in shape (time, 3).

  • n – Proton number density data in shape (time).

  • dva – Whether to remove mean value from magnetic field data. Default is False.

Return va/dva:

Alfven velocity or Alfven velocity with mean value removed.

spcphys_common_functions.parameters.coulomb_collisional_age module

TRACY P J, KASPER J C, ZURBUCHEN T H, et al., 2015. THERMALIZATION OF HEAVY IONS IN THE SOLAR WIND[J/OL]. The Astrophysical Journal, 812(2): 170. DOI:10.1088/0004-637X/812/2/170.

spcphys_common_functions.parameters.coulomb_collisional_age.calc_Ac(v_j: ~astropy.units.quantity.Quantity, T_j: ~astropy.units.quantity.Quantity, n_j: ~astropy.units.quantity.Quantity, v_i: ~astropy.units.quantity.Quantity, T_i: ~astropy.units.quantity.Quantity, n_i: ~astropy.units.quantity.Quantity, charge_number_i: int, mass_number_i: int, m_i: ~astropy.units.quantity.Quantity | None = None, charge_number_j: int = 1, mass_number_j: int = 1, m_j: ~astropy.units.quantity.Quantity | None = None, distance: ~astropy.units.quantity.Quantity = <<class 'astropy.constants.iau2015.IAU2015'> name='Astronomical Unit' value=149597870700.0 uncertainty=0.0 unit='m' reference='IAU 2012 Resolution B2'>) → float[source]

Calculate Coulomb collisional age, reproduced according to the algorithm of Tracy et al. (2015)

Parameters:

  • v_j – Field particle velocity, m/s

  • T_j – Field particle Temperature, K

  • n_j – Field particle number density, m^-3

  • v_i – Test particle velocity, m/s

  • T_i – Test particle Temperature, K

  • n_i – Test particle number density, m^-3

  • charge_number_i – Test particle charge number

  • mass_number_i – Test particle mass number

  • m_i – Test particle mass, kg, default None, calculated from mass_number_i with atomic mass constant

  • charge_number_j – Field particle charge number, default 1, proton

  • mass_number_j – Field particle mass number, default 1, proton

  • m_j – Field particle mass, kg, default None, calculated from mass_number_j with atomic mass constant

  • distance – heliocentric distance, AU, default 1 AU

Return Ac:

Coulomb Collisional Age

spcphys_common_functions.parameters.effectsize module

Modified from https://github.com/nbashir97/effectsize

spcphys_common_functions.parameters.effectsize.es_cohen(x1: ndarray | Quantity, x2: ndarray | Quantity, conf_interval: float = 0.99, log_scale: bool = False, skewed: bool = False) → Tuple[float, Tuple[float, float]][source]

Calculate Cohen’s d (Hedges’ g) effect size and confidence interval.

Parameters:

  • x1 – Data array 1.

  • x2 – Data array 2.

  • conf_interval – Confidence interval, default 0.99.

  • log_scale – If True, apply log scale to the data.

  • skewed – If True, apply rank-based transformation to the data.

Return es:

Cohen’s d effect size.

Return ci:

Confidence interval.

spcphys_common_functions.parameters.minimum_variance module

Modified from https://github.com/spedas/pyspedas/blob/master/pyspedas/cotrans_tools/minvar.py

spcphys_common_functions.parameters.minimum_variance.min_var(data: ndarray, verbose: bool = False)[source]

This program computes the principal variance directions and variances of a vector quantity as well as the associated eigenvalues.

Parameters:

data – Vxyz, an (npoints, ndim) array of data(ie Nx3)

Returns:

  • vrot – an array of (npoints, ndim) containing the rotated data in the new coordinate system, ijk. Vi(maximum direction)=vrot[0,:] Vj(intermediate direction)=vrot[1,:] Vk(minimum variance direction)=Vrot[2,:]

  • v – an (ndim,ndim) array containing the principal axes vectors Maximum variance direction eigenvector, Vi=v[,0] Intermediate variance direction, Vj=v[,1] (descending order)

  • w – the eigenvalues of the computation

spcphys_common_functions.parameters.plasma_beta module

spcphys_common_functions.parameters.plasma_beta.calc_beta(p_date: List[datetime] | ndarray, n: Quantity, b_date: List[datetime] | ndarray, b: Quantity, T: Quantity)[source]

Calculate plasma beta.

Parameters:

  • p_date – List of datetime objects for proton number density data.

  • n – Proton number density data in shape (time).

  • b_date – List of datetime objects for magnetic field data.

  • b – Magnetic field data in shape (time, 3).

  • T – Proton temperature data in shape (time).

Return beta:

Plasma beta.

  • T – Proton temperature data in shape (time).

spcphys_common_functions.parameters.vth_E_T module

Transformations between thermal velocity, energy, and temperature.

spcphys_common_functions.parameters.vth_E_T.E_to_T(E: Quantity) → Quantity[source]

Calculate temperature from energy.

Parameters:

E – Energy with units (e.g., E * u.J).

Return T:

Temperature with units (e.g., T * u.K).

spcphys_common_functions.parameters.vth_E_T.E_to_vth(E: ~astropy.units.quantity.Quantity, mass: ~astropy.units.quantity.Quantity = <<class 'astropy.constants.codata2018.CODATA2018'> name='Proton mass' value=1.67262192369e-27 uncertainty=5.1e-37 unit='kg' reference='CODATA 2018'>, n: int | float = 2) → Quantity[source]

Calculate thermal velocity from energy.

Parameters:

  • E – Energy with units (e.g., E * u.J).

  • mass – Mass with units (e.g., mass * u.kg). Default is proton mass.

  • n – Factor determining the type of thermal velocity. n=2 for most probable speed (Default), n=3 for root mean square speed, n=8/π for mean speed, n=1 for one-dimensional root mean square speed (for single direction temperature calculation).

Return vth:

Thermal velocity with units (e.g., vth * u.m/u.s).

spcphys_common_functions.parameters.vth_E_T.T_to_E(T: Quantity) → Quantity[source]

Calculate energy from temperature.

Parameters:

T – Temperature with units (e.g., T * u.K).

Return E:

Energy with units (e.g., E * u.J).

spcphys_common_functions.parameters.vth_E_T.T_to_vth(T: ~astropy.units.quantity.Quantity, mass: ~astropy.units.quantity.Quantity = <<class 'astropy.constants.codata2018.CODATA2018'> name='Proton mass' value=1.67262192369e-27 uncertainty=5.1e-37 unit='kg' reference='CODATA 2018'>, n: int | float = 2) → Quantity[source]

Calculate thermal velocity from temperature.

Parameters:

  • T – Temperature with units (e.g., T * u.K).

  • mass – Mass with units (e.g., mass * u.kg). Default is proton mass.

  • n – Factor determining the type of thermal velocity. n=2 for most probable speed (Default), n=3 for root mean square speed, n=8/π for mean speed, n=1 for one-dimensional root mean square speed (for single direction temperature calculation).

Return vth:

Thermal velocity with units (e.g., vth * u.m/u.s).

spcphys_common_functions.parameters.vth_E_T.vth_to_E(vth: ~astropy.units.quantity.Quantity, mass: ~astropy.units.quantity.Quantity = <<class 'astropy.constants.codata2018.CODATA2018'> name='Proton mass' value=1.67262192369e-27 uncertainty=5.1e-37 unit='kg' reference='CODATA 2018'>, n: int | float = 2) → Quantity[source]

Calculate energy from thermal velocity.

Parameters:

  • vth – Thermal velocity with units (e.g., vth * u.m/u.s).

  • mass – Mass with units (e.g., mass * u.kg). Default is proton mass.

  • n – Factor determining the type of thermal velocity. n=2 for most probable speed (Default), n=3 for root mean square speed, n=8/π for mean speed, n=1 for one-dimensional root mean square speed (for single direction temperature calculation).

Return E:

Energy with units (e.g., E * u.J).

spcphys_common_functions.parameters.vth_E_T.vth_to_T(vth: ~astropy.units.quantity.Quantity, mass: ~astropy.units.quantity.Quantity = <<class 'astropy.constants.codata2018.CODATA2018'> name='Proton mass' value=1.67262192369e-27 uncertainty=5.1e-37 unit='kg' reference='CODATA 2018'>, n: int | float = 2) → Quantity[source]

Calculate temperature from thermal velocity.

Parameters:

  • vth – Thermal velocity with units (e.g., vth * u.m/u.s).

  • mass – Mass with units (e.g., mass * u.kg). Default is proton mass.

  • n – Factor determining the type of thermal velocity. n=2 for most probable speed (Default), n=3 for root mean square speed, n=8/π for mean speed, n=1 for one-dimensional root mean square speed (for single direction temperature calculation).

Return T:

Temperature with units (e.g., T * u.K).
